Since October of 1950 the National Association of
Educational Broadcasters, acting in concert with
the American Council on Education, the Association
for Education by Radio-Television, the Association
of Land Grant Colleges and Universities, the National
Association of State Universities, the National
Council of Chief State School Officers, and the
National Education Association, has maintained the
Joint Committee on Educational Television. This
organization has represented the educational
establishment in the field of television.
The Committee has scheduled a Seminar for January
21, 1953 at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel in New York
City for the purpose of reporting to and receiving
guidance from the heads of its constituent organiza¬
tions. The meeting will continue on the 22nd with
representatives of foundations, FCC members, repre¬
sentatives of commercial broadcasting, and others,
and we would appreciate it if you could remain in
attendance that day as well.
It has been the function of the JCET to emphasize
the educational nature of educational television.
We need your help now and that of the officers of
the other constituent organizations of the Joint
Committee in charting policies for the future
activities of the JCET.
We are also inviting the Vice President of the NAEB,
Mr. Burton Paulu.
The Committee will, of course, be pleased to reimburse
you for your expenses incurred in attending this
Seminar.
Sincerelyvours
